awd_titl_txt: Computational Modeling of the Soot Size Distribution in Turbulent Reacting Flows: Leveraging Data Science Tools to Rapidly Accelerate Physics-Based Model Development and Validation
awd_abstract_narration:
Soot is an undesirable by-product of combustion formed during incomplete fuel-rich combustion of hydrocarbon fuels and has adverse effects on human health and the environment. These adverse effects vary with particle size, so controlling the distribution of soot particle sizes emitted from practical combustion systems is of increasing interest. Unfortunately, even the basic qualitative features of the soot size distribution in turbulent combustion are unknown. As a result, computational capabilities do not currently exist for efficiently predicting the soot size distribution in turbulent combustion. This project will develop fundamental understanding of the evolution of the soot size distribution in turbulent combustion using detailed, full-fidelity computational simulations, accelerated using deep learning. This knowledge will then be leveraged to develop a new computationally efficient modeling framework for predicting the evolution of the soot size distribution in turbulent combustion applicable to practical combustion systems. The new modeling framework will include a novel statistical model for the soot size distribution, a fundamentally new approach to capture the relatively slow chemistry of gaseous soot precursors, and a new turbulent transport model. The new modeling framework will be ultimately validated against experimental measurements. The software implementation of the new modeling framework will also be made publicly available for use by other researchers and in industry.

Computational approaches for predicting the soot size distribution in turbulent reacting flows are extremely limited, generally restricted to oversimplified and inaccurate soot models yet still computationally very expensive. While some limited evidence has suggested that the soot size distribution may sometimes be unimodal in turbulent flames and may preferentially generate very large soot particles, the influence of turbulence on the soot size distribution is fundamentally poorly understood. This project will develop a computationally efficient modeling framework for predicting the evolution of the soot size distribution in turbulent combustion. An Adaptive Sectional-Moment (ASM) model will be developed that combines a coarse sectional method in one internal coordinate with an advanced moment method in two internal coordinates within each section. ASM will be used to conduct Direct Numerical Simulations (DNS), accelerated using a combination of deep learning and data-derived manifolds, to provide unprecedented insights into the influence of turbulence on the soot size distribution. These databases will be further used to address two key modeling challenges in Large Eddy Simulation (LES) relevant to the soot size distribution. The slow chemistry of Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons (PAH) will be captured in an accurate yet consistent manner though a new partially non-equilibrium manifold model, and new models for the small-scale turbulent transport of soot will be developed utilizing physics-based and data-based approaches. Ultimately, the new LES modeling framework with ASM will be validated against the DNS databases and experimental measurements of the soot size distribution in turbulent flames.

por.por_cntn:
A new computationally efficient approach for predicting the soot size distribution in turbulent reacting flows was developed during this research project. Soot particles are carbonaceous nanoparticles formed during fuel-rich combustion. Their emission from combustion systems has detrimental effects on human health and the environment. Of specific note, soot emissions from aircraft engines have an influence on aviation-induced contrails, which have a potentially large yet uncertain influence on global climate.

 

Traditionally, soot predictions in turbulent reacting flows have leveraged the method of moments, which computes only mean quantities of soot, such as the soot volume fraction, number density, and average size. The use of the method of moments was simply due to computational tractability. However, particles of different sizes have different influences on humans and the environment, so the soot particle size distribution also needs to be known. Unfortunately, the sectional method, which requires equations for up to a hundred separate particle size classes, is far too expensive to couple with Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) and detailed soot models.

 

In this research program, the Bivariate Multi-Moment Sectional Method (BMMSM), which is like a sectional method but uses far fewer sections, was developed. Within each section, the local size distribution is reconstructed from a small set of moments within that section. Accurate size distributions can be obtained with as few as eight sections and two moments per section so sixteen total variables, and BMMSM was extended to detailed soot models for the particle morphology. When implemented within CFD (Large Eddy Simulation [LES]), simulations with BMMSM are much less than twice as expensive as simulations with the method of moments. Furthermore, for some flames featuring long residence times, BMMSM predicted a much more accurate soot volume fraction than the method of moments compared to experimental measurements due to small differences in soot oxidation, indicating that sectional-like methods such as BMMSM may also be required to predict mean soot quantities.

 

New LES models were also developed for the unresolved interactions between soot, turbulence, and chemistry. A prior model assumed that only mixing determined the distribution of soot with respect to the flame structure at unresolved scales so implicitly assumed that soot oxidation was infinitely fast. This model neglects smoking combustion in which soot passes through a flame unoxidized into fuel-lean mixtures. A new model was developed that considers finite-rate soot oxidation. In the limit of slow mixing and fast oxidation, the new model recovers the infinitely fast oxidation model. In the limit of fast mixing and slow oxidation, the new model allows for soot to pass into fuel-lean mixtures unoxidized. The local ratio of the mixing rate to the soot oxidation rate determines the nature of the model. This new model for was applied to multiple canonical turbulent nonpremixed flames and shown to improve predictions of both soot volume fraction and smoking combustion.

 

Finally, to model turbulent combustion in a computationally efficient manner, this research program considered so-called manifold models, in which the detailed thermochemical state is projected onto a physically-derived reduced-order manifold. In traditional manifold models, the combustion processes are oversimplified (e.g., two-stream nonpremixed combustion), and the manifold is precomputed and pretabulated for access during CFD. However, more general manifold models for multi-stream, multi-modal, non-adiabatic combustion are too complex for precomputation and pretabulation. With In-Situ Adaptive Manifold (ISAM), the manifold is instead computed on-the-fly during CFD (computing only what is needed) and stored for reuse with adaptive binary trees. In this research program, computational improvements were made to ISAM for efficient parallelization including synchronization of the binary trees across MPI processes and the use of hybrid MPI/OpenMP parallelization for manifold computations and binary tree retrieval. These improvements allow ISAM to be deployed for more complex manifold models. In addition, ISAM was coupled to the soot model and further developed for non-adiabatic combustion (soot is sensitive to the thermal environment). For heat losses, an iterative approach was developed to ensure that the enthalpy deficit was consistent between CFD and the combustion model.

 

The approaches developed as part of this research program are applicable beyond the applications pursued. The new soot statistical model could be applied to any aerosols or particles evolving in a laminar or turbulent flow. ISAM and its computational improvements could be deployed in any field of computational science with similar performance challenges: very expensive operations that are repeated numerous times during a simulation.

 

As part of this research program, one postdoctoral researcher and two graduate students principally supported by the project received training in combustion and soot physics, modeling, and computation; software development; high-performance computing; and technical communication. These early career researchers were also able to present their work at conferences and share their work through journal publications. The BMMSM soot model has also been made available to government researchers for implementation into publicly available Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) codes.
